i probably not add `ce` in default because

1. double the log size, could be a problem for distributed training
2. may slow down the performance if there is a large number of classes, such as full imagenent dataset

@feiyulv parallelism is a valid concern. I made some changes to set the max number of node to bulk to be 10 it doesn't end up using 1 stream most of the time. With num-embed=512, num-hidden=1024, num-layer=4, there's no significant performance difference compared to no-bulk.

Thank you, I tried using ``mxnet.rnn.RNNCell`` instead (see code below). It runs smoothly, however after some 50 or so iterations, I start getting NaN's in the outputs/parameters. The data input definitely contains no missing values and are normalised to the interval [0,1]. The same behaviour occurs for ``mx.rnn.SequentialRNNCell`` with layers of ``mx.rnn.LSTMCell``. Could you think of any explanations for this phenomenon? 

I have noticed that the maximum value of ``fc2_weighted_output`` approaches 1 before NaN's begin occurring, i.e. the NN gets more specific (it only outputs one of two classes due to a highly imbalanced dataset). I cannot see why this should lead to NaN's being introduced, though.

        num_hidden = self.num_hidden
        bs = self.batch_size
        data = mx.sym.Variable('data', shape=(bs, self.past_horizon+1, self.num_vars))
        weights = mx.sym.Variable('weights', shape=(self.num_classes))
        weights = mx.sym.tile(weights, reps=(bs, 1))
        W_1 = mx.sym.Variable('W_1', shape=(num_hidden, self.num_vars), init=mx.init.Uniform(0.7))
        W_1 = mx.sym.tile(W_1, reps=(bs, 1, 1))
        b_1 = mx.sym.Variable('b_1', shape=(num_hidden), init=mx.init.Uniform(0.7))
        b_1 = mx.sym.tile(b_1, reps=(bs, self.past_horizon+1, 1))
        matmul = mx.sym.batch_dot(lhs=data, rhs=W_1, transpose_b=True, name='matmul')
        fc1 = matmul + b_1
        encoded = mx.sym.Activation(fc1, act_type='sigmoid', name='encoded')
        rnn = mx.rnn.RNNCell(num_hidden=num_hidden)
        outputs, states = rnn.unroll(length=self.past_horizon+1, inputs=encoded, merge_outputs=True)
        outputs = mx.sym.Reshape(outputs, shape=(bs,-1, num_hidden), name='ABC')
        outputs = mx.sym.max(outputs, axis=1, name='outputs')
        fc2 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(outputs, num_hidden=self.num_classes, name='fc2')
        fc2_weighted = mx.sym.add_n(fc2, weights, name='fc2_weighted')
        loss = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(fc2_weighted, name='softmax')

Again, thank you so much for any feedback!

Sure I'll try to send an updated version with your suggestion tomorrow.

@eric-haibin-lin Is that possible to support a user define bulk when constructing  symbol, like this
```
a = mx.sym.dot(w, x, attr={'bulk: 0'})
a = mx.sym.BatchNorm(a, attr={'bulk: 0'})
a = mx.sym.relu(a, attr={'bulk: 0'})
b = mx.sym.dot(w, x, attr={'bulk: 1'})
b = mx.sym.BatchNorm(b, attr={'bulk: 1'})
b = mx.sym.relu(b, attr={'bulk: 1'})
```

Thanks for you reply!
Is there an option to turn on broadcasting for Symbols?
I am asking, because theno and tf are doing it, so different behavior then will require a wrapper for arithmetic operations and rewriting parts of existing code (what is not a cool thing in my case).

Let me reply my own questions :)

1. If there are multi GPUs, they take their slices from the batch according to work load list. For example, If work load list is [2 3 1], GPU 0 takes 2/6 of the batch, GPU 1 takes 3/6 of the batch and GPU 2 takes 1/6 of the batch in terms of the number of examples in the batch. The stats misleaded me since the batch size was very low comparing to the capacity of GPUs. After increasing the batch size, the speed results have become more consistent and reasonable. 

2. For multi-CPU case, in contrast to my claim in the question, there is a difference between single and two CPUs. However, the difference does not seem meaningful to me. I gave up deeper examination since I've decided not to use CPUs which are 5x-10x slower than GPUs.
Also, is it planned to have full support of float16 in general? For example, FullyConnected with float16 data seems to only work on GPUs/cuDNN.

recommendation system migration to nonlinearity is one of our focus as well. We did spark based flows for generalized matrix factorization for recommendation and topic modeling:
http://debasish83.github.io/spark-meetup-july2015/slides.pdf
https://spark-summit.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Quadratic-Programming-Solver-for-Non-negative-Matrix-Factorization-with-Spark-Debasish-Das.pdf
We are working on sparse support. Probably will take a month or two.

I get the same message when using `mx.nd.one_hot()`. Try casting your indices array to `np.int32`:

```python
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np

idxs = mx.nd.array([1,0,2,0])
mx.nd.one_hot(idxs.astype(np.int32), 3)
```

This seems to solve the problem for me, even though the error message doesn't say anything about types. Perhaps a cast is needed inside `mx.nd.one_hot()` in order to support the functionality from the docs? Or an `assert indicies.dtype == np.int32` so the error is more clear.

**Edit:** I just found the same problem in `mx.nd.batch_take()`. Casting to `np.int32` worked there as well.

@moveforever  yeah I mean
both of them

I tryed to fix it by modifying optimizer.py.Updater.__call__(...) as following:
```python
def __call__(self, index, grad, weight):
    """Update weight given gradient and index"""
    if index not in self.states:
        self.states[index] = self.optimizer.create_state(index, weight)
    ####---- what I added
    else:
        if weight.context != self.states[index][0].context:
            self.states[index] = tuple([x.copyto(weight.context) for x in self.states[index]])
    ####----
    self.optimizer.update(index, weight, grad, self.states[index])
```

But I'm not sure whether it is a suitable solution.

Ah yes, that will get it through on my end too. Alternatively, you can set the type in the constructor.
```
mx.nd.one_hot(mx.nd.array([1,0,2,0], dtype=np.int32), 3)
```

However, I will second then that the operator should do an astype for you if the input type is not int32.

Are you sure you need to run multiple threads running inference in parallel? MXNet already does parallel computing. Check this: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/5437

For OSX users, this requires xcode8
is xcode8 common? what was the the requirement before?

xcode8 is needed to support ```thread_local``` keyword for c++11. I think it is an reasonable choice if we enforce c++11. 

We can add compatibility macros for earlier version as we did for MSVC. Though I don't know how to detect xcode version via macro.
I am not an OSX user though, maybe @pluskid can tell a bit more about this

I have xcode 8, which comes with MacOS Sierra (the latest stable release). There are probably some people who still runs older version of MacOS. But updating clang should be easy. Usually the only reason that I kept an old version of clang is that nvcc might complain that the latest clang is not supported. 

e.g. some old reports:
https://devtalk.nvidia.com/default/topic/967644/mac-osx-cuda-8-0-not-compatible-with-clang-8-0-0/
https://github.com/arrayfire/arrayfire/issues/1384

Not sure nvcc has updated support for clang8 yet. I do not have NV cards in my new laptop so I do not know this.
@ap-hynninen Can we modify embedding to ignore out of range labels or clip them to range?
I see, @pluskid do you know anyway to detect if the env is xcode8? It is not an issue of clang version. but instead an issue of xcode not ship thread_local ABI until xcode8
We are refactoring to remove label_names entirely: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/loss
I'm still on El Capitan and xcode8 is available through app store update too.

http://mxnet.io/tutorials/python/symbol.html
http://mxnet.io/architecture/program_model.html

@tqchen What do you mean by xcode vs clang? Just to clarify, there is a package called 'xcode command line tools' that contains clang and related tools. I do not normally install xcode on my machine, but install this command line tools only in order to use clang. I have been able to compile mxnet fine. Do you mean this PR actually requires the full xcode?

Is there any reference where you see the thread_local ABI and xcode? Or is there a branch that I should try to test compile?

For detecting, do you mean pragmatically (e.g. some macro defined in C/C++)? Or just to detect it in a script? `clang --version` gives the version and my guess is that this is the same versioning for the xcode (GUI).
```
$ clang --version
Apple LLVM version 8.0.0 (clang-800.0.42.1)
Target: x86_64-apple-darwin16.4.0
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin
```
It should be doable. I'll look into this.

one of my mbp has LLVM version `7.3.0`. when we started mxnet, my version is `5.0.0`. We can definitely upgrade our test server, but dose it affect users who install mxnet by `pip` but have old xcode ?

For pip distribution (currently CPU/openblas only on OSX), we're using Xcode8 already. There's virtually no additional run-time dependencies for running those. See https://travis-ci.org/dmlc/mxnet-distro/jobs/202877795#L5140-L5144

Yes
